data.title: A hidden Gem
data.text: If you are ever in Jackson, TN you must stop by the Rock-a-Billy Hall of Fame. Henry has a personal passion for all of the unique memorabilia that is there. This is an hidden Gem in downtown Jackson. Be sure to ask Henry about his boxing career.

data.title: Interesting
data.text: If you have the time stop. You will see the story of this particular type of music. See a pair of Carl Perkins blue suede shoes. You are bound to learn something.

data.title: Good for history buffs
data.text: Good place to stop for tourists.nice part of history of Jackson,to.history of rocknrolland Blues/country.rock-a-hilly.

data.title: Great Musical Museum
data.text: This is musical heritage kept in trust by A gentleman named Henry who used to be the Toyota Dealer in the town who's a great personal friend of Carl Perkins, the writer and singer of Blue Suede shoes and has many great stories to tell of Carl's life an many others.  And the song which was arguably the birth of RocknRoll.  A nice personal tour, where you can play Carl's guitar and maybe play the drums that Elvis's drummer DJ Fontana played, just like we did.  A big thrill.

data.title: Friday Nights
data.text:
Friday Nights are a lot of fun. $5.00 cover, no alcohol served, children welcomed. Live Band- Glen Anthony & Family with featured local artists. And te rockabilly dancers. Cold drinks onsite.
It's fun, 7:00-9:30pm indoors

data.title: Very memorable with much laughter and happiness!
data.text: We felt Henry's enthusiasm when he greeted us at the door!  His knowledge of rockabilly music was impressive and his collections were equally amazing. We had a chance to "sing" Blue Suede shoes while "playing" Carl Perkins's guitar.  We also played the drums which Elvis's drummer once played.  We felt like famed singers and musicians for a brief moment :)  At one point, musicians from Sweden arrived and were in town as part of their US tour.  How amazing!  As we absorbed Henry's positive energy, we felt like we were in the era of Elvis and Carl Perkins.  Henry also surprised us with delightful stories about his younger days and his connection to Elvis Presley.  The entire experience was extremely memorable!  We left the museum full of positive energy, happiness, and laughter.

data.title: Sign said open - no one answered after buzzing
data.text: This was on our must see list while in Jackson. We had trouble with parking as most spaces were marked for an hour. With the court house nearby, we expect this may be monitored. The sandwich board outside said OPEN. The door was locked but a note said to use the buzzer as they might be in the back. We buzzed several times - short, long - over a period of 8 minutes. No one responded. This was around 2 pm. It looked like an interesting place through the glass. :(

data.title: One of the highlights of our trip to Tennessee
data.text: My boyfriend and I were visiting Tennessee and this place was one of the absolute best stops of our trip. Henry was such a nice guy it was a true honor meeting someone with such knowledge and appreciation for an excellent kind of music. I highly recommend this place to anyone planning on visiting this area of Tennessee. Henry has stories to share that you will not forget and the memorabilia that you get to see are incredible. If I am ever around in this area again, I will definitely make a point to stop here again. Thank you Henry for your passion, hospitality and giving us a wonderful tour!

data.title: INCREDIBLE!
data.text: This place and the tour was amazing and incredible!  You will never forget it!!! My teenagers were enthralled by Mr. Henry Harrison! He gave the tour and talked about the famous rock a billy singers he knew personally!  We even played on the drums from Elvis's summer!  Thank you so much Mr.  Harrison!

data.title: Stay off them Blue Suede Shoes!!!
data.text: Carl Perkins, a local star (he even had his own restaurant here, but it has since closed), is featured... you have to see his guitar!  Get your picture taken with the drums played by DC Fontana, see Wanda Jackson and Elvis Presley here as well.  Cough up $10 and get a tour to see videos of Johnny Cash, Wanda Jackson, the Jordanaires, Brenda Lee and more.  Bring the younguns and show them what REAL music is!

data.title: Very Limited
data.text: Old run-down building. Limited displays. Mostly old pictures and junk. Not worth your time. A lot better museums that cover the same people in Nashville.

owner_response.author: Rockabilly2014, General Manager at International Rock-A-Billy Hall of Fame, responded to this review
owner_response.text: Pleasant and glowing reports come from the Vast Majority of our tourists.  We are delighted with the over whelming positive response of our guests.  Please view the responses, given by tourists from from across the United States and from around the world.  Most say this is the finest musical tour they have ever taken in the United States of America.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Great, fun surprise by stopping at this museum!
data.text: Wow!  What a neat stop.  We found this by accident , just driving by as we were looking for something else.  I made my husband stop because of the mural.  Then he asked if I wanted to go inside.  I had no idea what it was so I thought why not!  And so thrilled we did.  Mr. Henry Harrison was just the sweetest man and was such a good story teller.  It was really neat to hear him share stories of the past and of working with the greats!  Had no idea we would be playing the drums and guitar, too.  Big fun!

data.title: That was so interesting
data.text: Meeting Henry was one of our highlights on the road. His first-hand accounts of all the Rock'n'Roll stars and especially Carl Perkins were interesting and touching all the same. A really authentic journey through time and music

data.title: So different - so authentic!
data.text: Henry is such a lovely guy and a great storyteller! We didn't know what to expect when we entered these rooms full of unique exhibits with walls full of names of visitors. It reminded me a lot of my grandpa's attic and that's exactly how it was. A treasure hunt with Henry who gave us a very personal tour with so many authentic stories about the real personalities behind the Johnny Cash, Carl Perkins and other celebs we thought "to know". The passion of his storytelling really touched my heart. Thank's a lot Henry. We will never forget.

data.title: I had no Idea
data.text: I don't believe I have ever had a tour like this before. Henry was our tour guide. He had lived so much of the story he was telling, he made it all come alive. The stories of growing up in the same depression project with Johnny Cash and how many of the songs he wrote and sang were from his personal childhood. And then getting to play W. S. Holland's drums. What a "HOOT"!

data.title: Henry Harrison brought it to life
data.text: Compared with other museums there is not so much to see, but the quality of the memorabilia and the anecdotes made the visit very special. Henry has personally known people like Carl Perkins, D J Fontana, Wanda Jackson and many other in the rockabilly world very well, and has a wealth of fascinating stories and reminiscences. Playing drums owned by DJ, and 'Blue sude shoes' on the guitar used by Carl was a highlight

data.title: Awesome!
data.text: A stop at this museum was one of the bright spots in my trip to Tennessee.  Henry Harrison is a wonderful host. His stories are so animated and interesting. Spent 90 minutes with us touring us around his precious museum. He gave us a great drum lesson and let us sign the walls. An absolute must for music fans!

data.title: Interesting Info and Wonderful Host!
data.text: Henry Harrison was a wonderful host for this tour. We had been to Graceland a couple of days before, and the information he provided was so much more personable! If you are looking for things to see and learn in Jackson Tn. stop by and ask Henry for the tour. Just wish we had had more time to watch all the videos and hear more stories!! Henry,Thank You for your wonderful insight to a side of rock and roll I knew very little about!

data.title: Do you want more people to be interested ?
data.text: What a waste of time. It was a two large rooms in the building  which when I was young was used for youth cubs. There was some information about half a dozen starts of the 1950/60s but you would have to have been ‘immersed; in the stuff then and had to have had a recent update for much  of this to be useful. To the average catholic  music  fan who was interested in learning more it all just sailed over my head.  The custodian  was engaged  in a ’love in ‘ with two people from that era and I didn’t really  exist – after ten minutes I had walked around and I left . It seemed run by amateurs for the interest of those who already knew a lot – a decling population and the genre looked like it will continue to die away as they wont capture any new interest behaving like it does.

data.title: For every real music fan, not to be missed
data.text:
The international rockabilly hall of fame is for every real music fan who wants to understand the history of rockabilly and the musicians who changed everything.  From blues to country, hillbilly to rock, owner Henry Harrison guides you through the people he knew personally and grew up with; Carl Perkins, Johnny Cash, Elvis Presley and Jerry Lee Lewis to name a few.
The collection of memorabilia is amazing; original records, drumsets, photos, paintings and lots more. Mr Harrison shares a lifetime of stories with an emphasis on conveying these musicians not just as 'stars' but as genuine people just like all of us.  DON'T MISS IT!
